HEA.fit package¶

Package contents¶

Package in order to:

  • Perform fits and save the result: HEA.fit.fit

  • Manage the parameters of the fit: HEA.fit.params

  • Perform fits: HEA.fit.fit

  • Get characteristics of zFit PDFs: HEA.fit.PDF

Submodules¶

HEA.fit.PDF module¶

  • Get the number of d.o.f. of a model

  • Get the \(\chi^2\) of a model

  • Get the mean/std of an array

HEA.fit.PDF.get_chi2(fit_counts, counts)[source]¶

Get the \(\chi^2\) of a fit

fit_countsnp.array or list

fitted number of counts

countsnp.array or list

number of counts in the histogram of the fitted data

returnsfloat

\(\chi^2\) of the fit

HEA.fit.PDF.get_mean(pull)[source]¶

Get the mean of an array, excluding non-valid values.

pullnumpy.array

Array

mean_pull: float

mean of the array

HEA.fit.PDF.get_n_dof_model(model)[source]¶

Get the number of d.o.f. of a zfit model. A d.o.f. corresponds to a floated parameter in the model.

model: zfit.pdf.BasePDF

Model (PDF)

n_dof: int

number of d.o.f. in the model

HEA.fit.PDF.get_n_dof_params_recurs(params, params_seen=[], n_dof_previous=0)[source]¶

Recursive function to get the number of d.o.f. of a parameter

paramszfit.pdf.Parameter or zfit.pdf.ComposedParameter

Parameter

params_seenlist(str)

list of the names of the parameters that have been seen so far

n_dof_previousint

number of d.o.f. counted so far

n_dof: int

number of d.o.f. contained in the list of parameters that aren’t in the list of parameters already seen, to which is added the number of d.o.f. already seen previously.

params_seen: list(str)

list of the names of the parameters that have been seen so far

HEA.fit.PDF.get_reduced_chi2(fit_counts, counts, n_dof)[source]¶

Get the reduced \(\chi^2\) of a fit

fit_countsnp.array or list

fitted number of counts

countsnp.array or list

number of counts in the histogram of the fitted data

n_dofint

number of d.o.f. in the model

returnsfloat

reduced \(\chi^2\) of the fit

HEA.fit.PDF.get_std(pull)[source]¶

Get the standard deviation of an array, excluding non-valid values.

pullnumpy.array

Array

mean_pull: float

Standard deviation of the array

HEA.fit.fit module¶

  • Define some PDFs

  • Define the parameters from a dictionnary of training variables

  • Perform a fit (using zfit)

  • Check if the fit has an error (if it did not converge, has not a positive-definite hesse, …)

HEA.fit.fit.check_fit(result)[source]¶

Check if the fit has gone well. If a check has gone wrong, point it out.

resultzfit.minimize.FitResult

result of the minimisation of the likelihood

Bool

False if something has gone wrong in the fit. True if the fit has gone smoothly.

HEA.fit.fit.crystall_ball_or_gaussian(mu, sigma, obs, alpha=None, n=None)[source]¶

return a Crystall Ball (CB) or gaussian PDF

  • Gaussian if alpha or n is None

  • CB if none of them are None

muzfit.Parameter

mean

sigma: zfit.Parameter

standard deviation

obs: zfit.Space

Space

alpha: zfit.Parameter

\(\alpha\) parameter of the tail

n: zfit.Parameter

\(n\) parameter of the tail

zfit.PDF.Gauss or zfit.PDF.CrystallBall

PDF

HEA.fit.fit.define_zparams(initial_values, cut_BDT=None, num=None)[source]¶

Define zparams from the dictionnary initial_values

initial_valuesdict

{“name_variable”: {“value”:, “low”:, “high”:, “floating”:}}

cut_BDTfloat

performed cut on the BDT (BDT > cutBDT)

numinteger

Index of the fit. add ";{num}" at the end of the variable/ the other functions I wrote allow to ignore the ";{num}" in the name of the variable. This is used manely in order to define a parameter several times (when tuning their values to make the fit convergent)

zparamsdict[str, zfit.Parameter]

Dictionnary of zfit Parameters whose keys are the name of the variables and:

  • if cut_BDT is None, the key is just the name of the variable

  • else, the key is "{name_variable}|BDT{cut_BDT}"

HEA.fit.fit.launch_fit(model, data, extended=False, verbose=True)[source]¶

Fit the data with the model

modelzfit.pdf.BasePDF

Overall PDF for the fit

datazfit.data.Data

Data that will be fitted to

extendedif True

Define or not an extended loss function

verboseBool

print or not the result of the fit

result: zfit.minimize.FitResult

result of the minimisation of the likelihood

paramDict[ZfitParameter, float]

Result result.params of the minimisation of the loss function (given by launch_fit())

HEA.fit.fit.save_params(params, name_file, uncertainty=True, dic_add=None, folder_name=None, remove=None)[source]¶

Save the parameters of the fit in {loc['json']}/{name_file}_params.json

paramsdict[zfit.zfitParameter, float]

Result 'result.params' of the minimisation of the loss function (given by launch_fit())

name_filestr

name of the file that will be saved

uncertaintybool

if True, save also the uncertainties (variables that contain ‘_err’ in their name)

dic_adddict or None

other parameters to be saved in the json file

folder_namestr

name of the folder

removelist[str] or str or None

if not None, string to be removed from the names of the parameters

HEA.fit.fit.sum_crystalball_or_gaussian(muL, muR, sigmaL, sigmaR, frac, obs, alphaL=None, alphaR=None, nL=None, nR=None)[source]¶

Return the sum of 2 crystall ball PDFs with tails in opposite side (left or right) or Gaussian PDFs. If the alpha or n is None, the corresponding distribution (left or right) is a gaussian.

muLzfit.Parameter

mean of the left distribution

muRzfit.Parameter

mean of the right distribution

sigmaL: zfit.Parameter

standard deviation of the left distribution

sigmaR: zfit.Parameter

standard deviation of the right distribution

obs: zfit.Space

Space

alphaL: zfit.Parameter

\(\alpha_L\) parameter of the left tail of the left distribution

alphaR: zfit.Parameter

\(\alpha_R\) parameter of the left tail of the right distribution

nL: zfit.Parameter

\(n_L\) parameter of the left tail of the left distribution

nL: zfit.Parameter

\(n_R\) parameter of the right tail of the right distribution

zfit.PDF.SumPDF

PDF sum of 2 crystall ball or Gaussian PDFs.

HEA.fit.params module¶

  • Retrieve params

  • Print the result of a fit as a latex table

  • Some formatting function of the dictionnary containing the fitted parameters

HEA.fit.params.get_params_without_BDT(df_params, retrieve_err=False)[source]¶

In the keys of the dictionnary, remove the text from | onwards, except ‘_err’

df_paramsdict

It is supposed to contain the result of the fit, saved in the json files. For instance:

  • {'alphaL': value, 'alphaL_err': value ...}

  • {'alphaL|BDT-0.5': value, 'alphaL|BDT-0.5'_err': value ...}

retrieve_errbool

if True, include the error of the variables in the file, i.e., the variables whose name contains '_err'

dict

Formatted dictionnary

With my notations, for a BDT cut BDT > 0.2, the variables’ names ends with '|BDT0.2'. Then, this function will the a variable named 'variable|BDT0.2' into a variable named 'variable'.

HEA.fit.params.get_params_without_err(params)[source]¶

get the list of variables from the dictionnary of fitted parameters (including errors)

paramsdict

fitted parameters {'alphaL': value, 'alphaL_err': value ...}

list

list of variables (excluding the error variables, whose name contain the '_err' string.

HEA.fit.params.json_to_latex_table(name_json, path, latex_params, show=True)[source]¶

transform a json file that contains the fitted parameters and uncertainties into a latex table The latex table is stored into a .tex file in {loc['tables']}/{name_json.tex}

name_jsonstr

name of the json file to load also the name of the future .tex file that will be saved

pathstr

path of the json file compared to loc['json'], the default folder for json files.

latex_paramsdict

alternative name of the parameters (in latex)

showbool

if True, print the content of the created latex table code

HEA.fit.params.retrieve_params(file_name, folder_name=None)[source]¶

Retrieve the parameters saved in a json file

file_namestr

name of the file

folder_namestr

name of folder where the json file is (if None, there is no folder)

librarystr

‘json’ or ‘pickle’

byte_read: bool

Read in byte mode

Python object or dic

dictionnary that contains the parameters stored in the json file in {loc['json']}/{folder_name}/{name_data}_params.json

HEA.fit.params.show_latex_table(name, path=None)[source]¶

Print the latex table that contains the result of a fit. It prints the content of the tex file in {loc['table']}/{path}/{name}_params.tex

namestr

name of the fit which we want to get the latex table with its result

pathstr

path of the .tex file from loc['tables'], where the .tex file is

the latex table must have been already generated, for instance with json_to_latex_table().
